summary: a total of 132,000 cases of melanoma and 2–3 million cases of NMSC are reported per annum globally. extensive exposure to sunlight has been closely associated with skin cancer. juglanin exerts inhibitory activity against the inflammatory response, as well as cancer growth (6–8) a previous study indicated that NF-B may serve an important role in the maintenance of skin homeostasis, as well as regulation of various types of cell proliferation, resistance to apoptosis and survival. c-Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK) and p38 have been reported to serve an important role in cell apoptosis and proliferation. treatment a total of 40 SKH-1 hairless mice (age, 5–6 weeks; weight, 20 g) were initially obtained from Jackson Laboratory (Bar Harbor, ME, USA) the mice were divided into four groups: the control (Con) group (without any UVB irradiation and juglanin treatment), the model (Mod) group (UVB irradiation), and the 10 and 20 mg/kg juglanin-treated groups, which were treated with juglan fresh tissue samples were fixed in formalin for 48 h at room temperature. tissue sections (5-m thick) were then fixed onto slides. endogenous peroxidase was blocked with 3% H2O2, and non-specific proteins were blocked with 10% goat serum. cell culture and treatment B16F10 murine melanoma cells and Hs68 human foreskin fibroblast cells were purchased from American Type Culture Collection (Manassas, VA, USA) the cells were maintained in a monolayer culture in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (DMEM; Gibco, Grand Island, NY, USA) Flow cytometry analysis Cancer cell apoptosis was calculated via flow cytometry. cells were harvested and washed three times with PBS. apoptosis was assessed using a flow cytometer. qPCR was conducted using the iQTM SYBR-Green Supermix. cDNA was synthesized from total RNA using the mirVana miRNA Isolation kit. western blotting Melanoma cells were homogenized in 10% hypotonic buffer. total protein (40 g) were loaded and proteins were separated using 10% SDS-PAGE. membranes were then blocked with 5% skim milk Tris buffered saline with 0.1% Tween 20 (TBST) incubation with horseradish peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibody (1:2,500; cat. no. 6721; Abcam) at room temperature for 2 h. the membrane was then developed using ECL (thermo Fisher Scientific, Inc.), and exposed to Kodak X-ray film. AKT (1:1,000; cat. no. 81283; Abcam), p-mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR; 1:1,000; cat. no. ab109268; Abcam), poly (ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP; 1:1,000; cat. no. ab13907; Abcam), cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK1; 1:1,000; cat. no. ab134175; Abcam mice were exposed to ultraviolet radiation at a dose of 600 mJ/cm2 in groups and were euthanized 24 or 72 h after each irradiation session. the animals were administered various doses (10 and 20 mg/kg) of juglanin by gavage. fresh tissue samples were fixed in formalin for 48 h at room temperature. tissue samples were then stained with hematoxylin and eosin. the stained tissue sections (5-m thick) were then observed under a microscope. the cells were maintained in a monolayer culture in a modified Eagle's medium (DMEM; Gibco, Grand Island, NY, USA) the cells were supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS; Gibco), 0.012% penicillin G, 0.027% streptomycin, 0.022% sodium pyruvate and 0.26% sodium bicarbonate at 37°C. apoptosis was assessed using a flow cytometer (BD Biosciences, Franklin Lakes, NJ, USA) after 15 min incubation at room temperature in the dark. fluorescence was detected at an excitation wavelength of 480 nm via FL-1 (530 nm) and FL-2 filters (585 nm) the number of apoptotic cells was then analyzed using Win-MDI software. qPCR was conducted using the iQTM SYBR-Green Supermix. cDNA was synthesized from total RNA using the TaqMan miRNA RT kit. western blotting Melanoma cells were homogenized in 10% hypotonic buffer. the final supernatants were obtained by centrifugation at 10,800 g for 20 min at 4°C. protein expression levels were defined as grey value using ImageJ (version 1.4.2b, Mac OS X; National Institute of Health, Bethesda, MD, USA) all experiments were performed in triplicate and done three times independently. polymerase (PARP; 1:1,000; cat. no. ab13907; Abcam), cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK1; 1:1,000; cat. no. ab134175; Abcam), p53 (1:1,000; cat. no. ab26; Abcam), p21 (1:1,000; cat. no. ab109199; Abcam), caspase-8 (1:1,000; cat. no. ab25901; Abcam), and PCNA (1: UVB exposure led to upregulated epidermal thickness in the Mod group. administration of juglanin (10 and 20 mg/kg to mice) led to suppression of epidermal hyperplasia and inflammatory cell infiltration compared with in the control mice. juglanin suppresses UVB-induced p38/JNK and PI3K/AKT activity. p38 and JNK phosphorylation levels were increased in mice following UV exposure compared with in the control group. however, juglanin treatment significantly reduced the increased expression of p-p38 and p-JNK compared with in the control group. PI3K, p-AKT and p-mTOR were determined. p-AKT, p-mTOR and p-mTOR were determined. treatment with juglanin significantly reduced the protein expression levels of IL-1, TNF- and IL-6 in the skin of UVB-exposed mice compared with in the Mod group. NF-B is an essential regulator that contributes to the release of proinflammatory cytokines (27). p-NF-B was conducted on tissue sections. representative photomicrographs from each group were shown. data are presented as the means standard deviation of three independent experiments. western blotting was conducted and relative protein expression levels of cyclin D1, CDK1 and PCNA were determined. equal protein loading was confirmed by stripping the immunoblot and reprobing it for GAPDH. immunofluorescence analysis of caspase-3 was conducted on tissue sections. representative photomicrographs from each group were shown. juglanin induced no significant cell death in Hs68 fibroblast cells. the present study indicated that UVB exposure led to a significant downregulation in the viability of B16F10 cells. however, 10 mJ/cm2 UVB induced no apparent cell death of normal Hs68 human fibroblast cells. results indicated that treatment of UVB-irradiated B16F10 cells with 2.5, 5, 10 and 20 M juglanin increased the percentage of cell death. UVB and juglanin cotreatment enhances apoptotic cell death and induces caspase activation and PARP-1 cleavage. juglanin led to a substantial increase in UVB-induced apoptosis. effects of juglanin on major protein regulators of p38/JNK and cell proliferation-associated signals in UVB-irradiated B16F10 cells via western blotting. the MAPK pathway, which is activated in virtually all melanomas, regulates cell metastasis, proliferation and survival (13). Western blotting of p53, p27 and p21 activation in B16F10 cells 24 h post-UVB/juglanin treatment. data are presented as the means standard deviation of three independent experiments. present study explored the effects of juglanin on UVB-induced skin injury. juglanin exerted dose-dependent alterations in the appearance of skin vasculature 24 h after exposure. juglanin exerted dose-dependent alterations in the appearance of skin vasculature. representative photomicrographs from each group were shown (scale bar, 100 m) data are presented as the means standard deviation of three independent experiments. p38 and JNK phosphorylation levels were increased in mice following UV exposure compared with in the control group. p38/JNK and PI3K/AKT may be involved in the inhibitory effects of juglanin on skin cancer. Western blotting was conducted and relative protein expression levels of (A) p-p38 and p-JNK, and (B) PI3K, p-AKT and p-mTOR were determined. expression levels of proinflammatory cytokines were detected in the skin of UVB-exposed mice treated with juglanin. NF-B is an essential regulator that contributes to the release of proinflammatory cytokines. juglanin administration was able to reverse this UV-induced overexpression. western blotting was conducted and relative expression levels of inflammation-associated proteins, IL-1 and IL-18 were determined. immunohistochemical analysis of p-NF-B was conducted on 5-m sections. UVB exposure downregulated p53, p27 and p21 protein expression. juglanin administration to UVB-induced mice promoted p53, p27 and p21 expression. juglanin administration was able to reduce PCNA expression. the results of an immunofluorescence assay suggested that caspase-3 was suppressed following UV induction in mice. notably, juglanin significantly enhanced caspase-3 levels. caspase-3 is an essential regulator that leads to apoptosis (29). administered juglanin (2.5–30 M) did not induce B16F10 cell death. 20 and 30 M juglanin significantly reduced cell viability. juglanin induced no significant cell death in Hs68 cells. analysis of viability of B16F10 cells treated with Jun and/or UVB (5 mJ/cm2) for 24 h. *P0.05, **P0.01 and **P0.01 compared with the Con group. western blot analysis of C-caspase-3, C-caspase-8 activation and C-PARP in B16F10 cells 24 h post-UVB/juglanin treatment. p53, p27 and p21 were assessed to explore the role of juglanin in human skin cancer cells in vitro. p53, p27 and p21 were lowly expressed in the control group. these data indicated that juglanin may perform its role in skin cancer suppression via cell proliferation inhibition in vitro. juglanin is a natural compound extracted from crude polygonum aviculare, which exhibits inhibitory activity against inflammation and cancer growth (7). in vivo p38 MAPK and JNK MAPK pathway was inactivated by juglanin in UVB-treated animals, while apoptosis was induced by juglanin. juglanin-regulated apoptosis in the skin of mice with UVB irradiation. in vivo, UV reduced caspase activation and PARP cleavage. in vitro, only skin cancer cells were included. further study is required in future to reveal molecular mechanism. the PI3K/AKT pathway was activated in vivo and in vitro. juglanin was able to suppress inflammation via NF-B inactivation. p53 protein translocates to the nucleus and activates numerous DNA-binding proteins. juglanin significantly suppressed the protein expression levels of PCNA in the skin of UVB-exposed mice. cyclin D1 is an important proliferative marker, which regulates cell proliferation (47). overexpression of cyclin D1 is associated with the development and progression of numerous types of cancer.
